Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is aimed at supporting U.S.-based participants at the meeting "Young Geometric Group Theory VIII" to be held at the University of the Basque Country in Bilbao, Spain, from June 30th to July 5th, 2019. Geometric group theory is an active branch of mathematics that focuses on the interactions between the geometry and topology of mathematical spaces and the algebraic objects which capture their symmetries. As most of the participants will be graduate students and early-career mathematicians, the conference will help them learn about new developments in the field, communicate their research results, and spark new research collaborations. The conference will also promote the growing diversity that geometric group theory has enjoyed through the selection of its speakers and participants.


This conference is the eighth meeting of the "Young Geometric Group Theory" series, which has been held each year since 2012. The meeting features four types of events that are designed to bring graduate students and postdocs together with early-career and well-established researchers in order to foster an environment of learning and collaboration. The events include mini courses given by four established experts in the field, plenary talks given by junior researchers, informal discussion sessions, and poster sessions and lightning talks given by graduate students. The mini courses allow graduate students and postdocs to learn cutting-edge methods in geometric group theory both from their peers and from experts. Topics range from expanders to geometric structures and representations of discrete groups. The junior talks are a way to publicize the work of young researchers and to obtain feedback and foster new collaborations.
A website for the conference can be found at https://sites.google.com/site/yggt2019bilbao.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2019 edition of the Young Geometric Group Theory (YGGT) meeting took place at the University of the Basque Country in Bilbao, Spain, from June 30th to July 5th. YGGT is an annual event whose primary goal is to expose graduate students and young researchers to cutting edge research in geometric group theory and to give them a forum to discuss their own work with experts in related fields. Past meetings were in Poland, Israel, France, Belgium, Germany, the UK, and Switzerland. The 2019 meeting attracted more than 140 delegates from around the world, including 38 participants from the US.


This grant partially supported 30 US participants, all either graduate students or postdocs at US institutions. Among the supported participants, 11 were from underrepresented groups in mathematics, including 8 women, 1 person who identified as Hispanic, and 1 person who identified as LGBTQ. From feedback we received from US participants, the conference was a great success. In particular, according to our survey of US participants, 31.3 percent said they have continued a scientific collaboration at the conference, while 37.5 say they may have started a new one. Further, about 97 percent said they would recommend a future YGGT meeting to a fellow graduate student.


The meeting itself consisted of four main components: minicourses, plenary lectures given by recent PhDs, discussion sessions, and lightning talks. The minicourses were given by Ken Bromberg (University of Utah), Sara Maloni (University of Virginia), Alexander Lubotzky (Einstein Institute of Mathematics) and Henry Wilton (Cambridge University) and covered an array topics at the forefront of Geometric Group Theory. The six plenary lectures were given by young researchers Tarik Aougab (Brown University), Oren Becker (The Hebrew University of Jerusalem), Sebastian Hurtado (University of Chicago), Kasia Jankiewicz (University of Chicago), Dawid Kielak (Bielefeld University), and Jenya Sapir (Binghamton University). A typical day concluded with discussion sessions where attendees could request further explanations on mini­courses and research talks. This special aspect of YGGT creates an atmosphere of enquiry and learning and is the hallmark of these meetings. Finally, the five-minute lightning talks gave all participants the opportunity to introduce themselves and their research to the other participants.

 

YGGT was organized in partnership with University of the Basque Country, the Basque Government, ERC grant 336983, and Ikerbasque - Basque Foundation for Science, as well as the NSF. The next YGGT meeting is planned for February 2020 in Saint-Jacut-de-la-Mer, France.
